author: @WechselWissen
text: Hello,  first of all, thank you for your great videos! Your outstanding way of presenting the content really does the trick for better understanding and remembering.  I've got a remark / question to this specific video. At 19:22, you say that the kernel trick *avoids* the transformation, and only calculates the high-dimensional relations.  Maybe I'm wrong, but as far as I understand the concept, this is an inaccurate description of what is happening. In my opinion, the benefit of the kernel trick is simply, that it does not execute all transformations at once and then stores them in the computers memory. Instead, it only calculates the transformation pair-wise, which is definitely needed in order to calculate the high-dimensional relations. So the transformations actually do get executed, but way less memory expensive, enabling the method of support vector machines to be used on large datasets. The amount of computation per se is not lowered.  Looking forward to your answer :)  Greetings from Germany!

author: @martinmartin6300
text: You could more easily eliminate the outliers by pairwise merging. Here, when you merge the two closest points together and they belong to different classes, you eliminate both. If the two points are of the same class, you replace both points with a point which is exactly in between them. This procedure eliminates outliers very well and you remove redundancy from your dataset which leads to a smaller dataset. By doing so, you can actually use nearest neighbour classification with pretty good results and controllable processing load. You could also apply max margin classifiers, with or without higher dimensional nonlinear mapping, as you have removed outliers.

text: I was sitting there desperately trying to revise and cram in all content before my postgrad Statistical Machine Learning exam. "Non-linear models" Josh answered, of course it was non-linear models, how could I forget such a sim- "Don't be embarrassed, we're all noble adventures on the Quest of Stat" Josh kindly said. I was nervous at this point, I didn't really know what to do, but I felt Josh's presence to be a benevolent one. Josh then approached and whispered in my ear "double bam", and we were then immediately sent to the astral-hyperplane in which we skipped around in checking out representations of models in 4d, 5d and even -3d realms..
